Compute the posterior probability to be above threshold, with a beta mixture prior on the response rate.

Source: R/postprob.R
postprob.Rd

Computes the posterior probability Pr(P_E > p | data). Prior is P_E ~ sum(weights * beta(parE[, 1], parE[, 2])), i.e., a mixture of beta priors. Default is one component only with uniform or beta(1,1).

Usage

postprob(x, n, p, parE = c(1, 1), weights, betamixPost, log.p = FALSE)

Arguments

x

number of successes

n

number of patients

p

threshold

parE

the beta parameters matrix, with K rows and 2 columns, corresponding to the beta parameters of the K components. Default is a uniform prior.

weights

the mixture weights of the beta mixture prior. Default are uniform weights across mixture components.

betamixPost

optional result of getBetamixPost in order to speed up the computations. If supplied, this is directly used, bypassing the other arguments (except p and log.p of course)

log.p

Return the log of the probability? (default: FALSE)

Value

The posterior probability that the response rate P_E is above p.

Details

We observed x successes in n trials. Note that x can be a vector.

Posterior is again a mixture of beta priors, with updated mixture weights and beta parameters.

Examples

## Example taken from Lee and Liu
##
## We observed 16 successes out of 23 patients
## We set a threshold of 0.60
## Assume a beta(0.6,0.4) prior for P_E
## Posterior will be a beta(16.6, 7.4), Pr(P_E > p | data) = 0.836
##
##

postprob(x = 16, n = 23, p = 0.60, par = c(0.6, 0.4))
#> [1] 0.8359808

## We could instead specify a mixture prior
## 2 component beta mixture prior, i.e., P_E ~ 0.6*beta(0.6,0.4) + 0.4*beta(1,1) and Pr(P_E > p | data) = 0.823
##
##
##

postprob(
  x = 16, n = 23, p = 0.60,
  par =
    rbind(
      c(0.6, 0.4),
      c(1, 1)
    ),
  weights = c(0.6, 0.4)
)
#> [1] 0.8226271
